listitem.para: a n-by-p matrix of doubles, where n is the number of linear equality constraints and p is the number of unknowns, the matrix in the linear equality constraints.
a n-by-1 matrix of doubles, the right hand side of the linear equality constraint.
a p-by-1 matrix of doubles, the linear part of the objective function.
a p-by-1 matrix of doubles, the initial guess.
a 1-by-1 matrix of doubles, a relative tolerance on x (default rtol=1.d-5).
a 1-by-1 matrix of doubles, the scaling factor (default sf=0.25). The scaling factor must satisfy 0<sf<1.
a function or a list, the output function.
a p-by-1 matrix of doubles, the solution.
a 1-by-1 matrix of doubles, the objective function value at optimum, i.e. the value of c'*xopt.
a 1-by-1 matrix of floating point integers, the number of iterations.

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: Computes x which solves the linear optimization problem:
Any optional parameter equal to the empty matrix [] is replaced by its default value.
If the scaling factor sf is closer to 1 (say sf=0.99, for example), then the number of iterations may be lower.
The output function outfun must have header
refsection.programlisting: stop = outfun ( iter , xopt , fopt , d )
refsection.para: where iter is the iteration index, xopt is the current point, fopt is the current function value and d is the current direction. Here, stop is a boolean, which is %t if the algorithm must stop.

It might happen that the output function requires additionnal arguments to be evaluated. In this case, we can use the following feature. The function outfun can also be the list (outf,a1,a2,...). In this case outf, the first element in the list, must have the header:
refsection.programlisting: stop = outf ( iter , xopt , fopt , d , a1 , a2 , ... )
refsection.para: where the input arguments a1, a2, ... will be automatically be appended at the end of the calling sequence.
